title: References (Part 1)
content:
References

References (Part 1)

This page contains the beginning of the paper's extensive reference list, documenting the scholarly works cited throughout the survey on Agentic Reasoning for Large Language Models.

Reference Format

References are numbered sequentially and include author names, paper titles, publication venues, and years. The references span foundational works on LLMs, chain-of-thought prompting, tool use, multi-agent systems, and various application domains.

Selected Key References

  • [1] Wei et al. - Chain-of-thought prompting elicits reasoning in large language models (2022)
  • [2] Denny Zhou et al. - Least-to-most prompting enables complex reasoning (2022)
  • [3] Luyu Gao et al. - PAL: Program-aided language models (2023)
  • [4] Shunyu Yao et al. - Tree of thoughts: Deliberate problem solving (2023)
  • [5] Shunyu Yao et al. - ReAct: Synergizing reasoning and acting (2023)
  • [6] Timo Schick et al. - Toolformer: Language models can teach themselves to use tools (2023)
  • [7] Yongliang Shen et al. - HuggingGPT: Solving AI tasks with ChatGPT (2023)
  • [8] Lei Wang et al. - A survey on large language model based autonomous agents (2024)
  • [9] Aditi Singh et al. - Agentic retrieval-augmented generation: A survey (2025)
  • [10] Yizheng Huang and Jimmy Huang - A survey on retrieval-augmented text generation (2024)
  • [11] Xingyao Wang et al. - OpenHands: An open platform for AI software developers as generalist agents (2024)

Analysis & Explanation

Reference Overview

Key Themes in References

The references cover major advances in reasoning prompting, tool integration, agent architectures, multi-agent coordination, and domain-specific applications. This comprehensive bibliography reflects the interdisciplinary nature of agentic reasoning research.
